key_points: Judge denies the use of 16 past incidents as evidence in the trial of former Minneapolis police officers charged in George Floyd's death.
Hennepin County Judge Peter Cahill did not provide an explanation for his decision, stating an opinion would follow.
Under Minnesota law, evidence of prior acts can be used to establish intent, knowledge, lack of mistake, or accident, among other things.
Derek Chauvin, charged with second-degree murder and manslaughter, will stand trial alone in March.
The three other former officers are charged with aiding and abetting and will stand trial together in the summer.
Prosecutors wanted to use eight previous incidents involving Chauvin to show a pattern of behavior inconsistent with police training.
Judge Cahill allowed evidence from two of the eight incidents involving Chauvin to be admitted.
The denied evidence included cases of Chauvin using force or restraint techniques similar to those used on Floyd.
Prosecutors also sought to admit evidence involving the other three officers and George Floyd's prior arrest, which was denied.
The Office of the Minnesota Attorney General has not commented on the judge's order.
